title: Former England striker Andy Carroll pleads not guilty to breaching non-molestation order
content:
Former England striker Andy Carroll has on Wednesday indicated a not guilty plea to breaching a non-molestation order.

Carroll, who plays for Dagenham & Redbridge, arrived at Chelmsford Magistrates’ Court on Wednesday on crutches and wearing a protective boot on his left leg following surgery last week.

The 37-year-old was arrested on April 27 last year, in relation to an alleged offence in the previous month.

Carroll said he wanted to have his case heard at a crown court rather than a magistrates’. He will next appear at Chelmsford Crown Court on March 4 for a plea and trial preparation hearing.

At that hearing, he will be asked to enter a plea and, if he pleads not guilty again, arrangements will be made for a trial. Carroll was placed on conditional bail.

A non-molestation order is a court injunction that usually stops someone from contacting another person and may also ban them from going near their home or workplace.

Breaching it is a criminal offence, with penalties ranging from a fine to up to five years in prison for the most serious cases.

Carroll, who was wearing a long green coat and Arne trainers, gave his address as Hackney, in East London.

He has had an injury-disrupted season for Dagenham, who play in the National League South, the sixth tier of English football.

Last week, Carroll posted on Instagram that he’d had surgery on his ligaments and a fracture. He missed the start of the season with a hamstring injury.

Carroll was once Liverpool’s record signing when he joined from Newcastle United on a dramatic deadline day in January 2011 for £35million (now $48m), along with Luis Suarez, who arrived from Ajax.

He went on to have spells at West Ham United, Reading, West Bromwich Albion, Amiens and Girondins de Bordeaux, before signing for non-League Dagenham last summer, where he is also a minority shareholder.
